awd_titl_txt: A Historical Study of Plant-Based Healing in the Age of Biomedicine
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, a growing dissatisfaction with biomedicine and rising rates of mental illnesses have led patients to search for therapeutic alternatives. Numerous news reports, best-selling books, television series, and scientific journal articles have increasingly begun to suggest that plant-based healing from Indigenous and folk practices offers a glimpse of hope for those whose suffering has been unaddressed or neglected by biomedicine. Such portraits often reinforce two conventional historical narratives: first, that these plant-based therapies were heralded as medical miracles from the late 1950s to the late 1960s before several scientific and cultural controversies transformed them into social pariahs, effectively ending scientific studies of psilocybin, lysergic acid diethylamide, and ayahuasca; and second, that these Indigenous and folk traditions are static, remaining unchanged over time and space. This doctoral dissertation project, however, shows that these historical narratives are incomplete. By focusing on ayahuasca, a plant-based concoction from the northwestern Amazon, this research offers an important corrective to these historical narratives and joins a growing body of research that emphasizes the dynamic relationship between folk and Indigenous knowledge and biomedicine.

This project reconstructs the relationship between scientists, local knowledge practitioners and healers, and ayahuasca from the late nineteenth century to the late twentieth century. Drawing on qualitative data gathered from archival research, oral histories and interviews, museum collections, and published sources, this historical project responds to two main research questions: 1) Why has ayahuasca sustained the attention of generations of multidisciplinary and transnational scientists? Preliminary archival research for this project suggests that scientists leveraged ayahuasca to professionalize their disciplines and develop bioprospecting opportunities with limited success. Folk and Indigenous perspectives are, however, often absent from these sources leading to this project’s second major research question: 2) What were the consequences of ayahuasca research, including humans and non-humans? Findings from this project will contextualize the influence of Indigenous and folk knowledge on modern science as well as the role of non-human actors in knowledge production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This STS project uses historical and ethnograpic research to examine the history of plant-based healing in the northwestern Amazon from the 1850s to the present, focusing on the borderlands of Brazil, Colombia, and Peru. More specifically, it focused on how different forms of folk and Indigenous plant-based healing intersected with the history of biomedicine, the history of the human sciences, and the history of the life sciences. Since the 1850s, naturalists, botanists, and physicians have eagerly documented the successes and failures of plant-based healing with the hopes of incorporating these remedies into Western medical practice. To do so, they often relied on the knowledge, practices, and relations of Indigenous Amazonian peoples, especially those of Shipibo- and Tucano-descent. 

This DDRIG supported archival research trips in Brazil, Colombia, and Peru. In Brazil, archival research was undertaken in the cities of Fortaleza, Manaus, and Florianópolis. In Manaus, research was undertaken primarily at the Arquivo Estadual do Amazonas and the Biblioteca Pública do Amazonas, while an interview was conducted at the home of an interlocutor. At the Arquivo Estadual and the Biblioteca Pública, government publications and correspondence were examined to assess whether and how public health officials in Brazil understood the relationship between plant-healing, public health, and biomedicine. This archival research was supplemented with a fieldsite visit outside of the Amazonian city. In Florianópolis, archival research and interviews were undertaken at the home of an anthropologist who has examined popular and plant-healing practices since the 1970s. He has collaborated with folk healers, botanists, physicians, and pharmacologists throughout his career. His archival materials included correspondence, fieldnotes, and photographs, which allowed for me to retrace extensive network of Latin American plant-healing researchers that has not yet been explored in the literature. This research was supplemented by work conducted at the Biblioteca Pública do Ceará in Fortaleza, which involved examinging microfilmed newspapers national and regional newspapers from the 1910s to the 1960s to gauge the public perception and understanding of plant-healing in the region. 

In Colombia, archival research was undertaken in Bogotá at the Archivo Central Histórico at the Universidad Nacional de Colombia, the Biblioteca Luis Ángel Arango, and the Instituto Colombiano de Antropología e Historia. At the Archivo Central Histórico at the Universidad Nacional de Colombia, I examined the correspondence and documents from the Faculties of Pharmacy and Medicine, both of which were crucial for identifying the "active agents" of healing plants throughout the region in the 1930s and 1940s. At the Biblioteca Luis Ángel Arango, and the Instituto Colombiano de Antropología e Historia I examined the personal papers of Colombian anthropologists who collaborated extensively with Tucano payés (healers) in their ethnographic fieldwork and subsequently sought to transform these healing plants into biomedical therapeutics. 

In Peru, archival research was undertaken at the Biblioteca Enrique Encinas at the Victor Larco Herrera Hospital and the Centro Cultural Peruano Britanico, both in Lima. The Biblioteca Enrique Encinas is held at the Victor Larco Herrera Hospital, the largest psychiatric hospital in the country, and thus is rich to explore how healing plants intersected with the history of psychiatry. There, I examined psychiatric correspondence and rare books to gauge whether and how medicinal plants figured into larger psychiatric care. Along similar lines, at the Centro Cultural Peruano Britanico, I examined the personal papers of a prominent Peruvian psychiatrist to assess if and how he incorporated healing plants into his practice. 

Initial research findings from this project have been presented at invited talks and conferences in Canada, the United States, and the United Kingdom, and will result in a doctoral dissertation to be defended in 2024. Results from this project are currently being prepared for submission as articles to journals in the history of science and science and technology studies and will eventually result in the publication of a historical monograph. I digitized the archival materials of my collaborator in Florianópolis, shared them with him, and am in the process of converting them to more accessible formats. I am in the process of preparing a report for the Ayahuasca Research Group, which includes physicians, scientists, social scientists, and traditional healers. 

This project demonstrates how Amazonian Indigenous and folk knowledges were crucial to the development of a global science and medicine of medicinal plants. While many histories have focused exclusively on the history of these plants in North America or Western Europe, this story demonstrates the Amazonian knowledges, practices, and relations were central to the creation of a global science and medicine of these substances.
